item.title: Supported file attachment document formats
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded:
BackChat.io processes certain document formats for metadata. This allows you to include queries for file attachments received from a message channel. This page lists all the supported document formats being processed by BackChat.io. [unordered_list style="green-dot"]
  • HTML
  • XML
  • Microsoft Office
  • OpenOffice
  • Apple iWorks
  • PDF
  • EPUB (Electronic Publication Format)
  • RTF (Rich Text Format)
  • Compression and packaging formats
  • Text formats
  • Audio formats
  • Image formats
  • Video formats
  • Java class files and archives
  • Mail formats
  • DWG
  • Fonts
  • Scientific formats
[/unordered_list]

item.title: Getting Started with BackChat.io
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded:
Get a BackChat.io developer account

Sign up for a free developer account by visiting the BackChat.io homepage at www.backchat.io. Once you've registered for and confirmed your account you will be able to login to the web interface. The web interface allows you to visually and easily define message channels and streams, as well as maintain all other account settings.

Getting your API key

Your API key should have been emailed to you when you first signed up for your BackChat.io user account. You can always find a copy of your current API key on the Developer Information page in the web interface. [caption id="attachment_145" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Your API key is displayed on the Developer Information page"][/caption] Please ensure your keep your API key private. Anyone who knows this information will have access to your account. If you suspect your API key is known by someone else, you can easily generate a new key on your Account page. This will invalidate any previous API keys. [divider]

Next: Defining your first Message Channel »

item.title: The Platform API Overview
item.dc:creator: Adam

item.title: About Activity Streams
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Activity Streams is an open data format for syndicating social activities around the web. Traditionally consuming data from social media APIs has been a painful experience, as their RSS & XML output followed differing schemas between APIs, or lacked the richness of the original data models. The Activity Streams format seeks to solve these issues by providing a common schema for social network developers to communicate in between services. Activity Streams have already been adopted by organisations including the BBC, Gnip, Google Buzz, Gowalla, IBM, MySpace, Opera, Socialcast, Superfeedr, TypePad, Windows Live, YIID, and many others. You can read more about Activity Streams on their website, http://activitystrea.ms/.

BackChat.io's usage of Activity Streams

BackChat.io implements version 1.0 of the Activity Stream JSON spec, with some custom extensions. See the Message Data Format's JSON Schema knowledge base entry for a full description of this JSON schema used in the results output streamed from BackChat.io.

item.title: Overview of BackChat.io
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
BackChat.io is easiest to describe as grep for the real-time web. The BackChat.io platform provides real-time message filtering and routing for social networks (or any real-time data source), in a unified, developer-focused interface. For the social web that means that you can start following certain users on a network, or define a search term, and you get those in a unified Activity Streams format. But for something more arcane, like say, log data, that means you can send it lines of text and have it extract out fields on which you can define filters. All of this happens in real-time and changes are reflected virtually immediately in open connections. It's a cloud-hosted Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS), with a utility billing model.

How does it work?

Incoming messages enter the system from any number of real-time data sources, like social network APIs. These messages are collated into a BackChat.io Stream (a collection of 1 or more Channels), on which BFL filters constantly run and filter out successful matches. The resulting messages are routed out of the platform to the developer's application, or alternatively out to another API (if supported). [caption id="attachment_158" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="High-level overview of BackChat.io's pipeline"][/caption]

BackChat.io consists of…

  • A web interface for configuring input channels and streams (including filters)
  • The BFL filter language to define filters easily
  • A Platform API for configuring input Channel's, Stream's, and all aspects of the user's account
  • HTTP and WebSocket endpoints for listening to live streams

Web Application Interface

The web application interface provides easy, visual tools for configuring channels and streams, as well as managing your account.

BackChat.io Filter Language (BFL)

Since not all messages received over a Channel are of interest to your particular application we need to be able to filter out only the messages of interest. BackChat.io provides a powerful filtering language, the BackChat Filter Lanague (BFL), for filtering messages received from a Message Channel. BFL's syntax is based upon the Lucene query language, so it should already be familiar to some developers.

The Platform API

The Platform API allows you to programmatically define all aspects of your BackChat.io account, including defining Channels and Streams. In fact, the web interface uses the Platform REST API itself for all it's functionality. Currently the Platform API is available via a REST interface, but the future roadmap also includes the introduction of a lighter-weight Platform Socket API.

Result Output Streaming

The end-result of the BackChat.io message processing pipeline is a real-time streaming result set, delivered to a subscriber as an ActivityStream JSON document. BackChat.io currently provides two streaming method: HTTP streaming being the most well-known, but also the newer and more efficient HTML5 WebSocket streaming.

item.title: BackChat.io Activity Stream JSON Format
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded:
Twitter Activity

When you get a notification from twitter the resulting json looks like:

item.title: FAQ
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded: [box type="note"]This content is being written...[/box]

item.title: Authorization
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Most of the Platform API's endpoints require authorization using an API key (which can be found in your welcome email or on the "developer" page in the web interface). [box type="info"]For security the API key is always sent over an SSL secured connection[/box] An authorized request must include the following HTTP header: 
Authorization: Backchat {YOUR_API_KEY}

Unauthorized request error

If you request an API endpoint without including the authorization header, or provide an invalid API key value, the API will return a "401 Unauthorized" response. This 401 response will include the following JSON document: 
{"data":null,"errors":[["","Unauthorized"]]}

item.title: Channel URIs in BackChat.io
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
A URI is a string of characters used to identify a resource on the Internet. URIs are used within BackChat.io to describe Message Channels (sources for your data) in a portable string form. More technically accurate, BackChat.io uses the hierarchical URI format to represent channels. URIs are well known formats, and described by the official RFC documents RFC2396 and RFC2732.

The structure of a Message Channel URI

A BackChat.io Channel URI is composed of the following parts [highlight][scheme:][//authority][path][?filter][#fragment][/highlight]

scheme (required)

The scheme defines the message channel’s data source. For instance, twitter://backchatio would define a Twitter public timeline of all messages from the user backchatio.

authority (optional)

An authority is composed of the following sub-parts: [highlight][credentials@][host][:port][/highlight]
  • credentials (optional)
    Credentials are used to authenticate a user with the data source (if required). Not all message channel data sources are publicly available, some of them require access credentials. There are two types of credentials that can be passed to a message channel, oauth and username/password combinations (the choice between the two will be dictated by the data source).
  • host (required)
    Specifies the target on the data source, which is usually the username of a user for a given API, althought it can sometimes be a host server’s DNS name or IP address. For instance, on twitter this will be the twitter username (backchatio), while on RSS feeds this would be the server name (myserver.com). On Twitter, for instance, the source is the twitter username. Or, if the scheme was an IMAP email box, the source would be the IMAP host server, such as mail.gmail.com.
  • port (optional)
    Specifies the port on the host when the host is a server name (such as myserver.com:8080).

path (optional)

Depending on the channel data source, a path can be used to provide more specificity on where to collect data from. For example, a path on an RSS URI could be…
  • http://myserver.com/path/to/rss.xml

filter (optional)

The querystring on a channel is used to provide extra parameters on a channel. The most common usage is the q parameter, which is used to provide a BFL filter to execute over the channel described in the URI (note: this BFL string must be URI-safe encoded). [highlight]twitter://backchatio?q=text%3A%22new%20feature%22%#timeline[/highlight] In the above example the ?q=text%3A%22new%20feature%22% parameter is used to specify the URI-safe string text:"new feature". This filter would select all tweets from the twitter user backchatio regarding new feature releases (looking for the words “new feature”). Backchat allows you to send the filter as a separate field so you don't have to deal with the encoding of a query and it stays nice and readable.

fragment (optional)

Some messages can come from multiple sources within a message source. Twitter, for example, provides public timelines, as well as private direct-messages. These would be examples of resources within a twitter user’s account. The resources provides a way to select more precisely the type of message to be collected from the message channel. An example usage of a resource is twitter://backchatio#timeline, which would collect the public timeline of the backchatio user’s account.

Example URIs

Collect public timeline tweets from the backchatio twitter account

[highlight]twitter://backchatio#timeline[/highlight]

Collect email from the mail.example.com IMAP server

[highlight]imap://username:password123@mail.example.com[/highlight]

Collect private SMSs sent to or from an O2 mobile phone (using #Blue)

[highlight]hashblue://07512345678[/highlight]

item.title: About the BackChat Filter Language (BFL)
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
BFL is BackChat.io's powerful filtering language. It allows you to quickly and easily define filters on Streams, controlling which messages are passed into the resulting streaming output. BFL is itself based upon the Apache Lucene query syntax. Developers with Lucene experience should find BFL nearly identical to use.

Learn more

  • BFL filter syntax documentation
  • Example BFL filters

item.title: BFL Filter Syntax
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Terms

A filter is broken up into terms and operators. There are two types of terms: Single Terms and Phrases. A Single Term is a single word such as "test" or "hello". A Phrase is a group of words surrounded by double quotes such as "hello dolly". Multiple terms can be combined together with Boolean operators to form a more complex filters (see below).

Fields

Backchat supports fielded data. When performing a search you can either specify a field, or use the default field. The field names and default field is implementation specific. You can search any field by typing the field name followed by a colon ":" and then the term you are looking for. As an example, let's assume a BackChat stream item contains two fields, title and content and content is the default field. If you want to find the activity entitled "The Right Way" which contains the content "don't go this way", you can enter: 
title:"The Right Way" AND content:go
or 
title:"Do it right" AND right
Since text is the default field, the field indicator is not required. Note: The field is only valid for the term that it directly precedes, so the query 
title:Do it right
Will only find "Do" in the title field. It will find "it" and "right" in the default field (in this case the content field).

Term Modifiers

BackChat supports modifying filter terms to provide a wide range of searching options.

Wildcard Searches

BackChat supports single and multiple character wildcard searches within single terms (not within phrase queries). To perform a single character wildcard search use the "?" symbol. To perform a multiple character wildcard search use the "*" symbol. The single character wildcard search looks for terms that match that with the single character replaced. For example, to search for "text" or "test" you can use the search: 
te?t
Multiple character wildcard searches looks for 0 or more characters. For example, to search for test, tests or tester, you can use the search: 
test*
You can also use the wildcard searches in the middle of a term. 
te*t
Note: You cannot use a * or ? symbol as the first character of a search.

Fuzzy Searches

BackChat supports fuzzy searches based on the Levenshtein Distance, or Edit Distance algorithm. To do a fuzzy search use the tilde, "~", symbol at the end of a Single word Term. For example to search for a term similar in spelling to "roam" use the fuzzy search: 
roam~
This search will find terms like foam and roams. An additional (optional) parameter can specify the required similarity. The value is between 0 and 1, with a value closer to 1 only terms with a higher similarity will be matched. For example: 
roam~0.8
The default that is used if the parameter is not given is 0.5.

Proximity Searches

BackChat supports finding words are a within a specific distance away. To do a proximity search use the tilde, "~", symbol at the end of a Phrase. For example to search for a "apache" and "jakarta" within 10 words of each other in a document use the search: 
"jakarta apache"~10

Range Searches

Range Queries allow one to match documents whose field(s) values are between the lower and upper bound specified by the Range Query. Range Queries can be inclusive or exclusive of the upper and lower bounds. Sorting is done lexicographically. 
mod_date:[20020101 TO 20030101]
This will find documents whose mod_date fields have values between 20020101 and 20030101, inclusive. Note that Range Queries are not reserved for date fields. You could also use range queries with non-date fields: 
title:{Aida TO Carmen}
This will find all documents whose titles are between Aida and Carmen, but not including Aida and Carmen. Inclusive range queries are denoted by square brackets. Exclusive range queries are denoted by curly brackets.

Boosting a Term

BackChat provides the relevance level of matching activities based on the terms found. To boost a term use the caret, "^", symbol with a boost factor (a number) at the end of the term you are searching. The higher the boost factor, the more relevant the term will be. Boosting allows you to control the relevance of a document by boosting its term. For example, if you are searching for 
jakarta apache
and you want the term "jakarta" to be more relevant boost it using the ^ symbol along with the boost factor next to the term. You would type: 
jakarta^4 apache
This will make activities with the term jakarta appear more relevant. You can also boost Phrase Terms as in the example: 
"jakarta apache"^4 "Apache BackChat"
By default, the boost factor is 1. Although the boost factor must be positive, it can be less than 1 (e.g. 0.2)

Boolean Operators

Boolean operators allow terms to be combined through logic operators. BackChat supports AND, "+", OR, NOT and "-" as Boolean operators(Note: Boolean operators must be ALL CAPS). The OR operator is the default conjunction operator. This means that if there is no Boolean operator between two terms, the OR operator is used. The OR operator links two terms and finds a matching document if either of the terms exist in a document. This is equivalent to a union using sets. The symbol || can be used in place of the word OR. To search for documents that contain either "jakarta apache" or just "jakarta" use the query: 
"jakarta apache" jakarta
or 
"jakarta apache" OR jakarta

AND

The AND operator matches documents where both terms exist anywhere in the text of a single document. This is equivalent to an intersection using sets. The symbol && can be used in place of the word AND. To search for documents that contain "jakarta apache" and "Apache BackChat" use the query: 
"jakarta apache" AND "Apache BackChat"

+

The "+" or required operator requires that the term after the "+" symbol exist somewhere in a the field of a single document. To search for documents that must contain "jakarta" and may contain "backchat" use the query: 
+jakarta backchat

NOT

The NOT operator excludes documents that contain the term after NOT. This is equivalent to a difference using sets. The symbol ! can be used in place of the word NOT. To search for documents that contain "jakarta apache" but not "Apache BackChat" use the query: 
"jakarta apache" NOT "Apache BackChat"
Note: The NOT operator cannot be used with just one term. For example, the following search will return no results: 
NOT "jakarta apache"

-

The "-" or prohibit operator excludes documents that contain the term after the "-" symbol. To search for documents that contain "jakarta apache" but not "Apache BackChat" use the query: 
"jakarta apache" -"Apache BackChat"

Grouping

BackChat supports using parentheses to group clauses to form sub queries. This can be very useful if you want to control the boolean logic for a query. To search for either "jakarta" or "apache" and "website" use the query: 
(jakarta OR apache) AND website
This eliminates any confusion and makes sure you that website must exist and either term jakarta or apache may exist.

Field Grouping

BackChat supports using parentheses to group multiple clauses to a single field. To search for a title that contains both the word "return" and the phrase "pink panther" use the query: 
title:(+return +"pink panther")

Escaping Special Characters

BackChat supports escaping special characters that are part of the query syntax. The current list special characters are + - && || ! ( ) { } [ ] ^ " ~ * ? : \ To escape these character use the \ before the character. For example to search for (1+1):2 use the query: 
\(1\+1\)\:2

item.title: Example BFL Filters
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
[box type="note"]This content is currently being written...[/box] [box type="info"]Refer to the BFL Filter Syntax entry for more information on constructing filters, and available filter types.[/box]

Example 1: Searching text and hash-tags (including fuzzy searching)

BFL Filter

(text:(football OR soccer) AND tags:(wembly AND barcelona~))

Example matching message

off to watch football game between #barcelona and #someotherfootballteam at #wembly

Explanation

Search a message's text content for the word "football" or "soccer". The message must also contain two hash tags, #wembly and #barcelona. The tilde character, "~", at the end of "barcelona~" will cause this search term to be fuzzy: meaning anything spelt similarly to the word "barcelona" would also match (useful for hard to spell words). For instance, both "barcalona" and "barcelona" would match this filter.

item.title: Client Libraries
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Tools

  • Interactive debug console

Ruby

  • BackChat

item.title: Defining a Channel
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
All messages (or any real-time data) enter the BackChat.io platform through - what we call - a Message Channel (also referred to as a Channel). A Channel defines a real-time data source (such as Twitter, Email, SMS), as well as a target, which defines a specific resource within the data source. For example, a Twitter timeline for user @backchatio: would have a source type of Twitter, and a target of backchatio. [box type="info"]As with all configuration you can define a channel programmatically via the Platform API (see the Platform API Endpoint documentation for more information).[/box] For ease of use though you can also use the web interface to quickly define a Channel. We'll cover this process step-by-step in the remainder of this article.

Defining a Channel using the web interface

Upon logging into the web interface you'll find the "Channel" page link in the top navigation bar. Clicking this will take you to the empty channels listing, and instruct you to create your first channel. [caption id="attachment_147" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="An empty channels listing"][/caption] Clicking the "Create a Channel" button will take you to the following source selection screen, where you can choose the type of data-source API which from which you wish to collect messages.

Select your data source

There are many different data sources for BackChat.io, with many more being added over time. Since the list of sources may be quite long, you can use the category-navigation bar at the top of the form to narrow down the list, for instance, only showing "Social" or "Chat" data sources. Simply click the source's icon to proceed. [caption id="attachment_149" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Select the source API for the new channel"][/caption]

Specify the type of messages you wish to collect (optional)

Some sources can collect different types of messages. In which case you will be presented with a screen like the one below, asking you to narrow down your source selection. For example, the Twitter source can pull public-only messages from a public timeline, or public and private messages from an authorised Twitter Account (which requires OAuth permission to be obtained). [caption id="attachment_148" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Some channel sources can collect different types of messages"][/caption]

Specify the target to collect messages from

Now that you've selected the source of your channel's messages you will need to define the specific target resource to collect messages for. In a Twitter timeline's case this would be the Twitter username - such as backchatio. The configuration form will vary depending on the type of channel being configured. Once you've completed the configuration form clicking the "Create Channel" button will create your new channel and save it against your user account. It will then be instantly available for inclusion and filtering in a Stream. [caption id="attachment_150" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Specify the target for your new channel"][/caption] Your newly defined channel should now be displayed in a list-table on the Channel's page. [caption id="attachment_152" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Your new channel displayed in the Channel page's listing"][/caption] In the next section of this Getting Started guide we'll cover how to define your first Stream, feeding the channel you've just defined into it, and how to define a BFL filter to filter out specific messages of interest from it. [divider]

Next: Defining your first Stream »

item.title: Defining a Stream
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Following the BackChat.io "water" terminology, 1 or more Channel's flow into a Stream. A Stream is a way to group together related Channels, and to define the BFL filters to filter incoming messages. For example, you may want to create a "Technology News" stream which includes a number of popular Twitter timeline channels feeding into it. Connecting to the streaming results output for this Stream (on your command like using curl, for instance) would should you real-time notifications any time one of those Twitter accounts tweet. That's all well and good, but lets pretend you now wanted to make your stream more specific to web technology news. Now you can start to define BFL queries over your channels, and filter out only tweets referring to web technologies. This is the power of streams.

Section contents:

  • Introducing the Stream Builder
  • A Stream needs a name
  • Adding Channels to your Stream
  • Channel Filters
  • Saving a Stream
  • Previewing a Stream
[hr]

Introducing the Stream Builder

To make building streams as easy as possible we've built the Stream Builder - a rich javascript application that allows you to quickly configure and test streams. The Streams page, accessible in the web interface's top navigation, will show a tabular listing of all currently defined Stream's. Clicking one of these streams, or the "Create a Stream" button will launch the Stream Builder (as seen below). [caption id="attachment_157" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="An overview of the Stream Builder interface"][/caption] [hr]

A Stream needs a name

The first step is to give your stream a name. At the top of the window you'll find the Stream Slug text-field. The Stream URL is the URL that serves the streaming-results for the stream, which you'll connect to from your client (such as a simple curl command or via an fuller client library). You need to give each of your streams a unique slug. Slug's are human-readable parts of URLs, so must be compliant with URL formatting (try to keep it to letters, numbers, '-' and '_'s). [box type="info"]Don't worry, the Stream Builder will automatically slugify your ID when you tab-out of the ID field, in case it isn't already valid.[/box] [hr]

Adding Channels to your Stream

Now you need to define which Channels will flow into this Stream. The main central area of the Stream Builder interface is a large editable grid. Each row in this grid will define a Channel Filter: a Channel (identified by it's BackChat.io Channel URI), and the BFL filter to run over that Channel. You can add a new Channel Filter by clicking the "Add" button in the grid's menu bar, or by entering data into the bottom empty row of the grid. Clicking on a row's Message Channel URI column will display a drop-down list of all Channels defined within your account. You can also start typing into this field to narrow down Channel. [caption id="attachment_159" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Click on the Message Channel URI column to select a Channel URI from the list"][/caption] Once you've selected a valid Channel you can define the BFL filter to run against it. [hr]

Channel Filters

The real power of a Stream comes from it's ability to filter the messages flowing into from it's Channel's. The BackChat.io Filter Language (BFL) provides a number of powerful filters, including keyword, fuzzy keyword, wildcard, and range searching, as well as geo-location searching.

Example: simple text & tag filtering

To search a Channel for simple keywords and hashtags simply enter the BFL Filter column of a row, and enter a simple BFL filter like the following (obviously you'll want to pick words and tags that match your problem domain). 
text:"purple" AND tags:(monkey or dishwasher)
Simply give the field you wish to search, such as (text: or tags:) followed by the search term. The search term can be a single word (either quoted or unquoted) or a phrase (multiple words, but must be enclosed in quotation marks "for example"). You can join your filters too using simple boolean logic. In this example, we're filtering on a free text word, "purple", and either of the two hash tags, "monkey" or "dishwasher" And there you go, you can see how easy it is to search for keywords and hashtags within incoming messages. [box type="note"]But of course, there are many more filters that you can use: read the BFL Filter Language articles for full information on the filtering capabilities available.[/box] [box type="tick"]Want to include all messages from a Channel? If you don't want to filter any messages from a channel, simply leave the BFL filter blank, and all messages will flow into the Stream.[/box] [hr]

Saving a Stream

While you may have made changes to the Stream Builder, those changes have yet to be saved. At the top right hand corner of the screen you will see the "Save Stream" button. This button will be enabled as soon as changes are detected. [caption id="attachment_161" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Click the "Save Stream" button to save your changes"][/caption] Save your Stream by clicking the "Save Stream" button. This will validate your Stream configuration, and raise any issues found. [hr]

Previewing a Stream

It is often handy for debugging your filters to inspect the results collected from a Stream. To preview a Stream make sure you save any changes first. It will only ever preview the last-saved Stream configuration. Click the "Run Stream" button to preview a Stream's results. Each result will be be added as a row to the Results Preview grid, and will show the time collected, the Channel URI it was collected for, and a summary of it's content. [caption id="attachment_162" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="Click the "Run Stream" button to preview Stream results"][/caption] [box type="info"]View the complete JSON document for a result row Often the Summary column won't provide enough detail for you to debug against. To view the full JSON document for the result row click the magnifying glass icon in the first column (the View column) of a result row to open the JSON previewer window.[/box] [divider]

Next: Connecting to a Stream using curl »

item.title: Connecting to a Stream with curl
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
If you've been following along with the getting started guide you'll now have a configured Stream with at least a single Channel flowing into it. You are now ready to connect to your Stream via the Result Output Streaming API. curl is a great tool for debugging your Stream configuration. In the next section we'll see how to start streaming output results through a client library.

HTTP Streaming

The following curl command shows how to construct the URL for your stream, as well as how to pass in your API Key credentials as an HTTP header. 
curl -H "Authorization: Backchat $YOUR_API_KEY" https://stream.backchat.io/stream-slug
[divider]

Next: Connecting to a Stream with a client library »

item.title: Connecting to a Stream with a client library
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded: [box type="note"]This content is currently being written...[/box]

item.title: HTTP streaming
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
HTTP Streaming is a mechanism for sending real-time data to a client from a web server. This is achieved through a long-lived HTTP connection. A client wishing to listen to a BackChat.io Output Results Stream will connect to the URL, which will be held open by the server. As new results becomes available for the Stream they will be written to the client.

How to connect to an HTTP streaming Output Result Stream

As this is an authenticated API you will need to include the relevant Authorization HTTP header. See the Authorization entry for more information.

Finding the URL for your Stream's Output Result Stream

Each Stream within BackChat.io is assigned it's own unique Output Result Stream URL. This URL is found in the Stream's JSON document under the "outputResultStreamUrl" property, or from within the web interface. The Output Result Streaming URL for a Stream is composed using a simple template. All you need to do is insert your Stream's slug: 
https://stream.backchat.io/{stream-slug}

Connecting via cURL

For simple data collection or debugging purposes you can easily connect to the Output Result Stream URL using the command line tool cURL. 
curl -H "Authorization: Backchat {YOUR_API_KEY}" "https://stream.backchat.io/{STREAM_SLUG}"

item.title: WebSocket streaming
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
HTML5 WebSocket's are a more efficient streaming method than HTTP streaming, and are the preferred method for connecting to BackChat.io's Output Result Stream API. WebSocket's offer a bi-directional, full-duplex channel to stream data over. The WebSocket Output Result Stream is very similar in functionality to HTTP streaming. A client wishing to listen to a Stream's results will connect to the Output Results Stream URL. Once connected the client can configure which Stream's to listen to by sending a series of subscription requests over the WebSocket connection. As new results becomes available for one of the subscribed Stream's they will be written to the WebSocket, raising a WebSocket onmessage event.

How to connect to a WebSocket streaming Output Result Stream

Authorization

As this is an authenticated API you will need to include the relevant authorization API Key. To perform authorization over the WebSocket connection you must send a simple string containing the authorisation command string containing a JSON array. For instance... 
var ws = new WebSocket("wss://stream.backchat.io/");
var apiKey = "{YOUR_API_KEY}";
ws.onopen = function(e) {
  ws.send('["AUTH", "' + apiKey + '"]');
}

The WebSocket Output Result Stream URL

Unlike HTTP streaming you can subscribe to results from multiple Stream's within a WebSocket streaming Output Result Stream. Because of this there is no unique URL per Stream, rather a shared URL is used, wss://stream.backchat.io/. The wss:// protocol indicates that this is a secured WebSocket connection, encrypted with TLS. Once you have opened a WebSocket connection to this URL you will need to subscribe to the Stream's you wish to listen to. This simple setup handshake is covered below.

Connecting WebSockets, authorising, and subscribing to a Stream

All WebSocket connections must setup subscriptions to Stream's. This is done by sending a simple message string to the server over the WebSocket connection. The subscription command is a simple string of two words: the first word being the keyword "SUBSCRIBE", the second being the slug of any Stream defined within your account that you want to listen to. 
var ws = new WebSocket("wss://stream.backchat.io/");

ws.onopen = function(e) {
  /* Authorise access to the socket */
  var apiKey = "{YOUR_API_KEY}";
  ws.send('["AUTH","'+ apiKey +'"]');
};

ws.onclose = function(e) { /* handle close */ };

var authorised = false;
ws.onmessage = function(e) {
  if(!authorised)
  {
    if(e.data == '["AUTH"]')
    {
      /* Authorisation failed */
      console.log("Not authorised. Check your API Key is valid.");
    }
    else if(e.data == '["AUTHSUCCESS"]')
    {
      /* Successfully connected and authorised */
      authorised = true;
      /* Subscribe to results for slug-for-a-stream */
      ws.send('["SUBSCRIBE", "slug-for-a-stream"]');
    }
  }
  else
  {
    /* A message has matched one of the stream's channel filters */
    console.log(e.data)
  }
};

ws.onerror = function(e) { /* handle the error */ };

Unsubscribing from a Stream

You can also unsubscribe from a Stream once your WebSocket connection has been setup. 
ws.send('["UNSUBSCRIBE","slug-for-a-stream"]');

item.title: Core concepts & terms
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
This section covers a few core concepts and terms used within the BackChat.io data structures, and referred to throughout the BackChat.io documentation.

The core data models

[caption id="attachment_177" align="alignnone" width="550" caption="The 3 data models used within BackChat.io"][/caption]

User

The central data model of a BackChat.io account. This model stores information about the user account, and provides references to all configured Channels and Streams.

Message Channels (also referred to as Channels)

A Channel feeds real-time messages into BackChat.io's processing pipeline. The data model defines an incoming source to collect data from, such as Twitter, Email, RSS, or any of BackChat.io's supported APIs. In addition it can define a specific target resource. This is commonly a user name. For instance, a Twitter Channel would have a source of "Twitter" and a target of the Twitter username (like "backchatio"). Channel's themselves don't output results, but first need to be fed into a Stream.

Message Streams (also referred to as Streams)

The Stream data model brings together one-or-more Channel, and provides filtering over those incoming Channel's to pick out the messages of interest, removing the noise from the signal. The Stream configuration defines Channel's should flow into the Stream, as well as filters to pick which messages should flow into the Stream's Result Output Stream via HTTP or WebSocket.

item.title: Result Output Streaming
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded: After messages have been collected and filtered from a Stream, the final step of the BackChat.io pipeline is the outputting of results in a real-time data-stream. This section covers the specifics of connecting to the Result Output Stream endpoints using either HTTP or WebSocket's, plus other important information such as authorization, and a description of the Activity Stream JSON format used.

item.title: Authorization
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
All access to a Stream's Output Result Stream require authorisation against your user account via an API Key. When connecting to a an Output Result Stream the HTTP request must include the following HTTP header: 
Authorization: Backchat {YOUR_API_KEY}

Unauthorized request error

If you request an API endpoint without including the authorization header, or provide an invalid API key value, the API will return a “401 Unauthorized” response.

item.title: Data Sources
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
BackChat.io is designed to be flexible enough to accept real-time data from a range of network services. We are constantly building up our data-source collection capabilities. If you have an API which you would like to feed into BackChat.io, but we don't yet support it, please get in touch and suggest we implement it. [box type="note"]We're working towards an open source release of our Channel Connectors, allowing you to implement your own API connectors on the BackChat.io platform.[/box]

We currently collect data from:

  • Twitter
  • SMS
  • Web Feeds
  • Email

Coming soon:

  • LinkedIn
  • XMPP

item.title: Twitter
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
The Twitter data source allows you to receive notifications when users post new tweets or direct messages.

Collect the following...

  • Public timeline tweets and replies
    • Subscribe to a user's public Twitter timeline by username
    • Collect all tweets posted by the user, and any replies to those messages.
  • Public and protected timeline tweets and replies, Direct Messages (DMs)
    • Requires OAuth authorization from the user
    • Collect tweets from public and protected timelines
    • Collect Direct Messages (DMs) sent and received

Notes

  • Firehose filtering is not yet available.

item.title: Email
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
BackChat.io can collect email from an automatically generated email-dropbox address (your-stream-slug.your-username@stream.backchat.io) or from an IMAP or POP3 email server.

Collect the following...

  • Email from a dropbox address uniquely generated for your Stream
  • Email from an IMAP account
  • Email from a POP3 account

Notes

  • IMAP and POP3 will require account credentials

item.title: Web Feeds (Atom & RSS)
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
The Web Feeds data source allows you to collect updates from websites offering Atom and RSS feeds. BackChat.io operates a PubSubHubbub (PuSH) hub for near-instant collection of updates to Web Feed. If your target website publishes updates using PubSubHubbub these updates will be collected by BackChat.io in near real-time. Web feeds that aren't published using PubSubHubbub will be polled for changes at regular intervals, usually as defined by the Atom or RSS feed, or at some short default interval.

Collect the following...

  •  Updated post content from any web feed source, such as web pages, blogs, news articles, media, etc.

item.title: SMS
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Short Message Service (SMS) messages can be collected into BackChat.io easily for O2 customers using the hashblue.com API.

Collect the following...

  • SMS messages sent or received from an O2 mobile phone using the #Blue API

Notes

  • Requires OAuth authorisation from the mobile phone owner

item.title: 21st Sept '11 Release: Activity Stream
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded:
We are pleased to announce the initial release of the BackChat.io platform today. The team's been hard at work over the last month on some great new features in preparation for our beta launch (coming later this year).

Included in this release:

  • We standardized on JSON activity streams as output streaming format
  • API documentation
  • A new rich-client web UI for creating and testing Streams
  • Messages can now be buffered while a client is disconnected from a Stream. Connecting to a Stream will replay this buffer to the client
  • Database records now support versioning
  • The Output Streaming API has had a small revamp, making it more data friendly and intuitive
  • A number of backend stability changes

item.title: Invalid confirmation token
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
This error may be encountered when trying to confirm your email address and account after sign up.

Cause:

The Welcome email should include a link to confirm and activate your account. This is a one-time use link, and if used again may result in the following API response error message:
"Your confirmation token is invalid. It may have expired or been used already."

Resolution:

Continue as normal. Your account appears to have already been confirmed, and should be fully active.

item.title: Data source not found
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
This error is raised when specifying a message channel's URI with an invalid data source schema.

Cause:

When working with message channels and streams you may encounter the following error message:
"The data source `[source name]` was not found. Check it's valid and supported."
This message is raised when a channel URI references an invalid data source in it's schema. In a URI form, the schema is the protocol of the channel. An example format of a URI (named to identify each part)... 
schema://target#kind
The most common cause of this error is a spelling mistake on the source schema (such as "twittr" instead of "twitter"), or referencing a currently unsupported data source.

Resolution:

Check the spelling of your message data source, and check that it is a valid (and active) data source. Refer to the Channel URIs in BackChat.io article for more information on specifying channel URIs, and the current list of supported data sources to ensure the data source you are attempting to use is valid and active.

item.title: The site isn't working
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded: Adam here: just wanting to see what would happen if a user submitted a message to us. Not sure if we want this - I may disable it in the UI and push users to email and twitter instead.

item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Activity Streams is an open data format for syndicating social activities around the web.
Traditionally consuming data from social media APIs has been a painful experience, as their RSS & XML output followed differing schemas between APIs, or lacked the richness of the original data models.
The Activity Streams format seeks to solve these issues by providing a common schema for social network developers to communicate in between services.
Activity Streams have already been adopted by organisations including the BBC, Gnip, Google Buzz, Gowalla, IBM, MySpace, Opera, Socialcast, Superfeedr, TypePad, Windows Live, YIID, and many others.
You can read more about Activity Streams on their website, http://activitystrea.ms/. BackChat.io’s usage of Activity Streams BackChat.io implements version 1.0 of the Activity Stream JSON spec, with some custom extensions.
See the Message Data Format’s JSON Schema knowledge base entry for a full description of this JSON schema used in the results output streamed from BackChat.io.

item.title: Conflict while updating a message channel referenced by one or more message streams
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
The message channel you are attempting to update is currently referenced by one or more message streams. You'll need to force this operation.

Cause:

The message channel you are attempting to update is currently referenced by one or more message streams. Modifying the message channel would have undesired effects, as it would modify the behaviour of any existing message streams using the channel.

Resolution:

There are a couple of options available to overcome this error message. Instead of updating a message channel that is being referenced by message streams, you could instead create a new one (as this won't have any referencing conflicts). Alternatively, if you do actually want to go ahead and update the message channel, and update all the message streams referencing the message channel to the new state, pass the `force` parameter set to `true`.

item.title: Getting Started
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
[box type="note"]This content is currently being written.[/box]
Introduction This entry provides a step by step guide on how to get started with BackChat.io. Registering a BackChat.io user account Getting your API key Defining a Message Channel data source Defining a Message Stream Defining a BQL query Connecting to a Message Stream using curl Connecting to a Message Stream using a client library

item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded: [box type="note"]This content is currently being written.[/box]

item.title: Overview
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
This entry provides an overview of what BackChat.io does, it’s core concepts and data models. What is BackChat.io? BackChat.io is a hosted, developer orientated platform that collects and filters messages from a range of real-time data sources, including social media APIs.
[quote]BackChat.io is grep for the real-time web.[/quote]
BackChat.io is easiest to describe as grep for the real-time web.
For the social web that means that you can start following certain users on a network, or define a search term, and you get those in a unified Activity Streams format.
But for something more arcane, like say, log data, that means you can send it lines of text and have it extract out fields on which you can define filters. All of this happens in real-time and changes are reflected virtually immediately in open connections. Data Models At a high level there are a few data models that you need to understand: user, channels, and streams. User model The user model describes the user account, providing information about the user as well as their configured channels and streams. Message Channel model A Message Channel is, in BackChat.io terms, a configured real-time data source. An instance of a channel could be (but not limited to) a Twitter user’s timeline, an RSS feed, or a dropbox email address.
There are a wide range of Message Channel sources, allowing you to collect data from popular social network APIs and other real-time data sources.
Once a Channel is configured within BackChat.io it’s content is fed into the system, and can be filtered by Streams.
A Channel only defines the source of the data, all queries are done within the Stream model. This allows a Channel definition to be used within multiple Streams. Stream model A Stream brings together 1 or more Channels, and provides a way to define BQL queries across these Channels.
Once a Stream has been configured it’s filtered results are streamed to subscribing clients in real-time. BackChat Query Language (BQL) Since not all messages received over a Channel are of interest to your particular application we need to be able to filter out only the messages of interest.
BackChat.io provides a powerful query language for filtering messages received from a Message Channel.
BQL is based upon the Lucene query language, so it should already be familiar to some developers. The Messaging Pipeline Collect, Filter, Enhance, Route. BackChat.io’s pipeline can be described as Collect. Filter. Enhance. Route. Collect Incoming messages are collected from Channels Filter …before being filtered and collated within Streams. Enhance BackChat.io also provides the concept of data enhancements – ways of adding additional, richer data to a message.
[box type="note"]Enhancements are currently in development and have yet to be released (as of September 2011)[/box] Route Routing allows you define an output channel for a stream. You can think of BackChat.io as a smart network switch, accepting inputs on one port, filtering them, and outputting the results to another port.
For instance, your stream could route it’s results to a Twitter channel, posting each matching result as a new public timeline tweet.
[box type="note"]Routing is currently in development and have yet to be released (as of September 2011)[/box]

item.title: Supported file attachment formats
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
BackChat.io processes certain document formats for metadata. This allows you to include queries for file attachments received from a message channel.
This page lists all the supported document formats being processed by BackChat.io.
[unordered_list style="green-dot"]
HTML XML Microsoft Office OpenOffice Apple iWorks PDF EPUB (Electronic Publication Format) RTF (Rich Text Format) Compression and packaging formats Text formats Audio formats Image formats Video formats Java class files and archives Mail formats DWG Fonts Scientific formats
[/unordered_list]

item.title: Representing Channels as URI
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
URIs (Uniform Resource Identifier) A URI is a string of characters used to identify a resource on the Internet. URIs are used within BackChat.io to describe message channels (sources for your data).
More specifically BackChat.io uses the hierarchical URI format to represent channels.
URIs are well known formats, and described by the official RFC documents RFC2396 and RFC2732.
The structure of a message channel URI A BackChat.io message channel URI is composed of the following parts
[highlight][scheme://][//authority][path][?query][#fragment][/highlight] scheme (required) The scheme defines the message channel’s data source.
For instance, twitter://backchatio would define a Twitter public timeline of all messages from the user backchatio. authority (optional) An authority is composed of the following sub-parts:
[highlight][credentials@][host][:port][/highlight]
credentials (optional) Credentials are used to authenticate a user with the data source (if required).
Not all message channel data sources are publicly available, some of them require access credentials.
There are two types of credentials that can be passed to a message channel, oauth and username/password combinations (the choice between the two will be dictated by the data source).
host (required) Specifies the target on the data source, which is usually the username of a user for a given API, althought it can sometimes be a host server’s DNS name or IP address.
For instance, on twitter this will be the twitter username (backchatio), while on RSS feeds this would be the server name (myserver.com).
On Twitter, for instance, the source is the twitter username. Or, if the scheme was an IMAP email box, the source would be the IMAP host server, such as mail.gmail.com.
port (optional) Specifies the port on the host when the host is a server name (such as myserver.com:8080).
path (optional) Depending on the channel data source, a path can be used to provide more specificity on where to collect data from.
For example, a path on an RSS URI could be…
http://myserver.com/path/to/rss.xml
query (optional) The querystring on a channel is used to provide extra parameters on a channel.
The most common usage is the bql parameter, which is used to provide a BQL query to execute over the channel described in the URI (note: this BQL string must be URI-safe encoded).
[highlight]twitter://backchatio?bql=text%20has%20%22new%20feature%22%#timeline[/highlight]
In the above example the ?bql=text%20has%20%22new%20feature%22% parameter is used to specify the URI-safe string text has “new feature”.
This query would select all tweets from the twitter user backchatio regarding new feature releases (looking for the words “new feature”). fragment (optional) Some messages can come from multiple sources within a message source. Twitter, for example, provides public timelines, as well as private direct-messages. These would be examples of resources within a twitter user’s account.
The resources provides a way to select more precisely the type of message to be collected from the message channel.
An example usage of a resource is twitter://backchatio#timeline, which would collect the public timeline of the backchatio user’s account.
Example URIs Collect public timeline tweets from the backchatio twitter account [highlight]twitter://backchatio#timeline[/highlight] Collect email from the mail.example.com IMAP server [highlight]imap://username:password123@mail.example.com[/highlight] Collect private SMSs sent to or from an O2 mobile phone (using #Blue) [highlight]hashblue://07512345678[/highlight]
Available message channel URI schemes Please read the list of currently supported social networks and APIs.

item.title: Filter Syntax
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
BQL Query Syntax Terms
A query is broken up into terms and operators. There are two types of terms: Single Terms and Phrases.
A Single Term is a single word such as “test” or “hello”.
A Phrase is a group of words surrounded by double quotes such as “hello dolly”.
Multiple terms can be combined together with Boolean operators to form a more complex query (see below).
Note: The analyzer used to create the index will be used on the terms and phrases in the query string. So it is important to choose an analyzer that will not interfere with the terms used in the query string.
Fields
Lucene supports fielded data. When performing a search you can either specify a field, or use the default field. The field names and default field is implementation specific.
You can search any field by typing the field name followed by a colon “:” and then the term you are looking for.
As an example, let’s assume a Lucene index contains two fields, title and text and text is the default field. If you want to find the document entitled “The Right Way” which contains the text “don’t go this way”, you can enter: title:”The Right Way” AND text:go or title:”Do it right” AND right Since text is the default field, the field indicator is not required.
Note: The field is only valid for the term that it directly precedes, so the query title:Do it right Will only find “Do” in the title field. It will find “it” and “right” in the default field (in this case the text field).
Term Modifiers
Lucene supports modifying query terms to provide a wide range of searching options.
Wildcard Searches Lucene supports single and multiple character wildcard searches within single terms (not within phrase queries).
To perform a single character wildcard search use the “?” symbol.
To perform a multiple character wildcard search use the “*” symbol.
The single character wildcard search looks for terms that match that with the single character replaced. For example, to search for “text” or “test” you can use the search: te?t Multiple character wildcard searches looks for 0 or more characters. For example, to search for test, tests or tester, you can use the search: test* You can also use the wildcard searches in the middle of a term. te*t Note: You cannot use a * or ? symbol as the first character of a search. Fuzzy Searches Lucene supports fuzzy searches based on the Levenshtein Distance, or Edit Distance algorithm. To do a fuzzy search use the tilde, “~”, symbol at the end of a Single word Term. For example to search for a term similar in spelling to “roam” use the fuzzy search: roam~ This search will find terms like foam and roams.
Starting with Lucene 1.9 an additional (optional) parameter can specify the required similarity. The value is between 0 and 1, with a value closer to 1 only terms with a higher similarity will be matched. For example: roam~0.8 The default that is used if the parameter is not given is 0.5. Proximity Searches Lucene supports finding words are a within a specific distance away. To do a proximity search use the tilde, “~”, symbol at the end of a Phrase. For example to search for a “apache” and “jakarta” within 10 words of each other in a document use the search: “jakarta apache”~10 Range Searches Range Queries allow one to match documents whose field(s) values are between the lower and upper bound specified by the Range Query. Range Queries can be inclusive or exclusive of the upper and lower bounds. Sorting is done lexicographically. mod_date:[20020101 TO 20030101] This will find documents whose mod_date fields have values between 20020101 and 20030101, inclusive. Note that Range Queries are not reserved for date fields. You could also use range queries with non-date fields: title:{Aida TO Carmen} This will find all documents whose titles are between Aida and Carmen, but not including Aida and Carmen.
Inclusive range queries are denoted by square brackets. Exclusive range queries are denoted by curly brackets. Boosting a Term Lucene provides the relevance level of matching documents based on the terms found. To boost a term use the caret, “^”, symbol with a boost factor (a number) at the end of the term you are searching. The higher the boost factor, the more relevant the term will be.
Boosting allows you to control the relevance of a document by boosting its term. For example, if you are searching for jakarta apache and you want the term “jakarta” to be more relevant boost it using the ^ symbol along with the boost factor next to the term. You would type: jakarta^4 apache This will make documents with the term jakarta appear more relevant. You can also boost Phrase Terms as in the example: “jakarta apache”^4 “Apache Lucene” By default, the boost factor is 1. Although the boost factor must be positive, it can be less than 1 (e.g. 0.2)
Boolean Operators
Boolean operators allow terms to be combined through logic operators. Lucene supports AND, “+”, OR, NOT and “-” as Boolean operators(Note: Boolean operators must be ALL CAPS).
The OR operator is the default conjunction operator. This means that if there is no Boolean operator between two terms, the OR operator is used. The OR operator links two terms and finds a matching document if either of the terms exist in a document. This is equivalent to a union using sets. The symbol || can be used in place of the word OR.
To search for documents that contain either “jakarta apache” or just “jakarta” use the query: “jakarta apache” jakarta or “jakarta apache” OR jakarta AND The AND operator matches documents where both terms exist anywhere in the text of a single document. This is equivalent to an intersection using sets. The symbol && can be used in place of the word AND.
To search for documents that contain “jakarta apache” and “Apache Lucene” use the query: “jakarta apache” AND “Apache Lucene” + The “+” or required operator requires that the term after the “+” symbol exist somewhere in a the field of a single document.
To search for documents that must contain “jakarta” and may contain “lucene” use the query: +jakarta lucene NOT The NOT operator excludes documents that contain the term after NOT. This is equivalent to a difference using sets. The symbol ! can be used in place of the word NOT.
To search for documents that contain “jakarta apache” but not “Apache Lucene” use the query: “jakarta apache” NOT “Apache Lucene” Note: The NOT operator cannot be used with just one term. For example, the following search will return no results: NOT “jakarta apache” - The “-” or prohibit operator excludes documents that contain the term after the “-” symbol.
To search for documents that contain “jakarta apache” but not “Apache Lucene” use the query: “jakarta apache” -”Apache Lucene”
Grouping
Lucene supports using parentheses to group clauses to form sub queries. This can be very useful if you want to control the boolean logic for a query.
To search for either “jakarta” or “apache” and “website” use the query: (jakarta OR apache) AND website This eliminates any confusion and makes sure you that website must exist and either term jakarta or apache may exist.
Field Grouping
Lucene supports using parentheses to group multiple clauses to a single field.
To search for a title that contains both the word “return” and the phrase “pink panther” use the query: title:(+return +”pink panther”)
Escaping Special Characters
Lucene supports escaping special characters that are part of the query syntax. The current list special characters are
+ – && || ! ( ) { } [ ] ^ ” ~ * ? :
To escape these character use the before the character. For example to search for (1+1):2 use the query: (1+1):2

item.title: BackChat Filter Language (BFL)
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
BQL is BackChat.io’s powerful querying language. It allows you to quickly and easily define filters on Streams, controlling which messages are passed into the resulting streaming output.
BQL is itself based upon the Apache Lucene query syntax. Developers with Lucene experience should find BQL nearly identical to use.
[hr]

item.title: Come join us!
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded:
Backchat.io is hiring!

BackChat.io is easiest to describe as grep for real-time data. We’re busy developing a platform that makes sense of the data you send it (in real-time). For the social web that means that you can start following certain users on a network or define a search term and you get those in a unified activity streams format. But for something more arcane, like say, log data, that means you can send it lines of text and have it extract out fields on which you can define filters. All of this happens in real-time and changes are reflected virtually immediately in open connections. Our system is designed to allow for easy definition of data sources. Sources that currently feed into our system are Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, SMTP, RSS, ATOM, PubSubHubbub, and more. By next year we hope to provide dozens, if not 100’s, of API implementations. In the longer term we hope to provide more intelligent stuff like real-time reporting by allowing you to define aggregates like SUM, enhance data with secondary information, and many more crazy ideas. We’re aiming to build our system exclusively on existing standards described in RFC’s or the activity streams spec. However not everything we do is described in standards and that’s where we’ll try to extend an existing standard. Our use cases are wide, ranging from niche collaboration or social media apps, to communication/PR/marketing agencies, to telecommunications… We operate at an abstraction on a much lower level than most similar services; so many tools you see and use on the web today can be built with only a few lines of code in your favourite language on our platform. The entire system is built on dogfooding and practicing what we preach. So where it makes sense we rely on our own service, like with log processing. Our entire website is built using the API methods we expose to our customers. Our API integration language will be shared with our customers too.

How do you guys work?

We use a mix of technologies like scala, akka, mongodb, lucene, zeromq, dropbox, flowdock, skype, …. We apply agile principles to our development process, but this doesn’t mean we follow a doctrine that is being sold because some consultant wants to make some money. To us Agile development means: design for change. Which also means that the process we use is adapted to the people in the process and not vice versa. It’s about being productive and creating an environment where you want to work. At the moment, all of us work from home. We’re a team of 3, looking for a fourth team-member to start in September. We don’t care where or how you work, just that you deliver 40 hours worth of output, regular github pushes (so new code can be reviewed before it hits our integration branch) and, most importantly, passion!

Great! What are you guys looking for?

We’re looking for a passionate developer. This person ideally:
  • knows about concurrent and distributed programming
  • is well-versed in Scala
  • can accept a team decision, and understands that communication is the most important part of development as a team.
  • is polyglot (the ability to work with C#, node.js/javascript, ruby, python and/or php)
  • preferably knows XMPP beyond using the smack library
  • has used mongodb
  • knows Lucene
  • regular expressions have little or no secrets for you
  • does not believe in sugar-coating things and voices reservations early
  • No! Try not. Do, or do not. There is no try. (Some of us hope you’re a Star Wars fan too)
It’s a plus if you’ve done some of the following:
  • BIG data
  • Language parsing and development
  • Natural language processing
  • Statistics
  • knows how to express himself in simple english and not academic language
  • Netty server development / Java NIO
  • Jetty customization
  • Understands the problems communication agencies and social-media developers face
What we’re not looking for is someone who has little or no experience, community zealots and big framework lovers (I’m looking at you rails, lift, spring, …). We need doers! You do not have to live in the UK to work with/for us. We are firm believers in smarter remote-working, and our cloud-based infrastructure is designed to allow us to work from where we want.

Open-Source?

We use a lot of open source, and we believe in being good citizens and contribute back where we can. Some of the projects we use: casbah, akka, scalatra, lift-mongodb-record, lift-json, codahale metrics, databinder dispatch, … So far most of our contributions were to scalatra and peripheral to akka. If we come up with stuff that we all agree on should really be in an open source project then we will actually take the necessary steps to make that happen. Any open-source library we produce is licensed as MIT and uses as few dependencies as possible (be nice to people with complicated projects).

What’s the vision?

To build the best damned developer platform for social-media and real-time data! Quickly! Our service is primarily aimed at developers. We provide a metered, utility billing model. Depending on which bits and pieces of our infrastructure a developer uses we calculate a price per message for each incoming channel. At the end of the month they get a bill. This billing is updated in real-time so everybody knows exactly where they stand. For corporate customers we provide a behind-firewall-install license. This license fee may or may not include bespoke development or integration into their systems. Our founding customer has been O2/Telefonica. They’re using our platform in cool ways, but we can’t talk about that just yet (ssshh).

Who are the company?

Adam Burmister is the CEO of the company and has previously worked as team lead for the bbc.com homepage. He has also done assorted javascript libraries and was nominated for a webby award for his work at xero.com. He’s a Kiwi, so be warned, he sounds funny. Ivan Porto Carrero is the CTO and has previously almost published a book on IronRuby and has been an MVP for the last 2 years. Worked as an architect/consultant in the .NET sphere and met Adam while he was working as a senior development at xero.com It helps to know that Ivan is from Belgium, as an extremely low bullshit tolerance and it’s best to feed him at regular times with pre-approved snacks. Also, his english sounds funny. Stefan De Boey was our very first helper and we haven’t managed to scare him off, he’s actually happy with his job, but won’t say so because he’s Belgian and compliments make people suspicious where he’s from (not to mention the thought of making a government). Stefan typically starts his day between 11am and 12:30 and finishes around 20:00. Also, his english sounds funny.

Ok, I’m sold. How do I apply?

Great! We’re looking forward to meeting you. If you could, please start by emailing us your LinkedIn profile and preferably some recent open source projects you worked on, at team@backchat.io
item.excerpt:encoded: We're on the hunt for some amazing developers looking to work on one of the hottest real-time, big-data projects going on in London.

item.title: Knowledge Base front page
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the BackChat.io Knowledge Base: it's our collective knowledge on how to get up and running, and become an expert user, with the BackChat.io real-time message streaming platform. If you're new you may like to check out the BackChat.io overview and the Getting Started guide. More experienced users can find more detailed content on navigation to the right on this page, or by using the search box below.

Search the Knowledge Base...

item.title: Concepts & Terms
item.dc:creator: Support
item.content:encoded: This section covers a few core concepts used within the BackChat.io data structures. User The central data model of a BackChat.io account. This model stores information about the user account, and provides references to all configured Channels and Streams for the user account. Message Channels (also referred to as Channels) A Channel defines an incoming data source that feeds real-time messages into BackChat.io’s processing pipeline. Message Streams (also referred to as Streams) A Stream brings together one-or-more Channel, and provides filtering over those incoming Channel’s. This Stream configuration defines which messages should flow into the Stream’s Result Output Stream via HTTP or WebSocket.

item.title: An intro to remote working: The view from the window & the importance of the connection
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.content:encoded:
I started writing this blog post from the 5th floor of a Gold Coast apartment block, looking over the golden sands, and onwards to the blue pacific ocean, feeling happy to have been freed from the oncoming London winter.

Over the following week this post has been sitting as a draft on my browser tabs I've worked on this post from 3 different locations around Australasia: the Gold Coast apartment; sitting underneath a tree in Auckland's grassy Domain (park); the quiet sea-side town of Tauranga in New Zealand's Bay of Plenty.

We are opinionated founders (I suspect most founders are). As developers, Ivan and I, have worked for the large corporations of the world, as well as nifty startups. When it came time for us to form our own company, Mojolly, to build the BackChat.io platform, we've talked excitedly about how to incorporate our ideas and beliefs into a best-of-breed company; a place made for people like us.

One of our core belief's is in the benefits of remote-working: the ability to free ourselves of physical locations, to live and work anywhere (and provide the same freedom to our team members).
The concept of requiring people to co-locate their meat-bags into some pokey London office seems antiquated, when you consider the technology available to us provides us such freedom.

Our toolset is a vital ingredient in the remote-working stew: a mixture of collaboration software, cloud hosting, and bandwidth.
Bandwidth still seems to be the largest hurdle in a lot of the world. It's been 3 years since I left New Zealand, which in mobile connectivity has ranked as one of the most expensive places in the developed world. So it's been exciting to return, in late 2011, to see the new comer, *2 degrees*, entering the mobile telephony market and driving down prices.
While perhaps still not as cheap as other parts of the world, I can now at least get a pre-paid mobile-phone internet connection with a 12GB data-cap for NZD$150.
